sub.title: Adult Dosing
sub.mono:
• Acetaminophen overdose: oral: initial, 140 mg/kg ORALLY, then 70 mg/kg every 4 hours for 17 doses starting 4 hours after loading dose
  • Acetaminophen overdose: IV: body weight over 100 kg, loading dose, 15,000 mg in 200 mL of compatible solution (D5W, 0.45%NaCl, or sterile water for injection) IV over 60 minutes, then 5000 mg in 500 mL of compatible solution IV over 4 hours, followed by 10,000 mg in 1000 mL of solution IV over 16 hours; may continue beyond 21 hours if clinically indicated; adjust the total volume administered for patients requiring fluid restriction as clinically necessary
  • Acetaminophen overdose: IV: body weight 41 to 100 kg, loading dose, 150 mg/kg in 200 mL of compatible solution (D5W, 0.45%NaCl, or sterile water for injection) IV over 60 minutes, then 50 mg/kg in 500 mL of compatible solution IV over 4 hours, followed by 100 mg/kg in 1000 mL of solution IV over 16 hours; may continue beyond 21 hours if clinically indicated; adjust the total volume administered for patients requiring fluid restriction as clinically necessary
  • Acetaminophen overdose: IV: body weight 21 to 40 kg: loading dose, 150 mg/kg in 100 mL of compatible solution (D5W, 0.45%NaCl, or sterile water for injection) IV over 60 minutes, then 50 mg/kg in 250 mL of compatible solution IV over 4 hours, followed by 100 mg/kg in 500 mL of compatible solution IV over 16 hours; may continue beyond 21 hours if clinically indicated; adjust the total volume administered for patients less than 40 kg or requiring fluid restriction as clinically necessary
  • Acetaminophen overdose: IV: body weight 5 to 20 kg: loading dose, 150 mg/kg in 3 mL/kg of compatible solution (D5W, 0.45%NaCl, or sterile water for injection) IV over 60 minutes, then 50 mg/kg in 7 mL/kg of compatible solution IV over 4 hours, followed by 100 mg/kg in 14 mL/kg of compatible solution IV over 16 hours; may continue beyond 21 hours if clinically indicated; adjust the total volume administered for patients requiring fluid restriction as clinically necessary
  • Administration of anesthesia for procedure: nebulization into a face mask, mouth piece, or tracheostomy: 1 to 10 mL of the 20% solution or 2 to 20 mL of the 10% solution every 2 to 6 hours; usual dose is 3 to 5 mL of the 20% solution or 6 to 10 mL of the 10% solution 3 to 4 times daily
  • Administration of anesthesia for procedure: nebulization into a tent or croupette: individualize treatment; use the volume of the 10% or 20% solution that will maintain a very heavy mist in the tent or croupette
  • Administration of anesthesia for procedure: direct instillation into tracheostomy: 1 to 2 mL of a 10% or 20% solution may be given as often as every hour; usual dose is 1 to 2 mL of a 10% or 20% solution every 1 to 4 hours
  • Administration of anesthesia for procedure: percutaneous intratracheal catheter: 1 to 2 mL of 20% solution or 2 to 4 mL of 10% solution every 1 to 4 hours via a syringe attached to the catheter
  • Administration of anesthesia for procedure: intratracheal catheter into particular bronchopulmonary tree segment: 2 to 5 mL of the 20% solution via a syringe attached to the catheter
  • Atelectasis, Due to mucous obstruction: nebulization into a face mask, mouth piece, or tracheostomy: 1 to 10 mL of the 20% solution or 2 to 20 mL of the 10% solution every 2 to 6 hours; usual dose is 3 to 5 mL of the 20% solution or 6 to 10 mL of the 10% solution 3 to 4 times daily

  • Cystic fibrosis, Pulmonary complications; Adjunct: intratracheal catheter into particular bronchopulmonary tree segment: 2 to 5 mL of the 20% solution via a syringe attached to the catheter

  • Disease of respiratory system, chronic: nebulization into a face mask, mouth piece, or tracheostomy: 1 to 10 mL of the 20% solution or 2 to 20 mL of the 10% solution every 2 to 6 hours; usual dose is 3 to 5 mL of the 20% solution or 6 to 10 mL of the 10% solution 3 to 4 times daily
  • Disease of respiratory system, chronic: nebulization into a tent or croupette: individualize treatment; use the volume of the 10% or 20% solution that will maintain a very heavy mist in the tent or croupette
  • Disease of respiratory system, chronic: direct instillation into tracheostomy: 1 to 2 mL of a 10% or 20% solution may be given as often as every hour; usual dose is 1 to 2 mL of a 10% or 20% solution every 1 to 4 hours
  • Disease of respiratory system, chronic: percutaneous intratracheal catheter: 1 to 2 mL of 20% solution or 2 to 4 mL of 10% solution every 1 to 4 hours via a syringe attached to the catheter
  • Disease of respiratory system, chronic: intratracheal catheter into particular bronchopulmonary tree segment: 2 to 5 mL of the 20% solution via a syringe attached to the catheter
  • Hepatic failure, acute, Non-Acetaminophen Induced: 150 mg/kg/hr IV for 1 hour, 12.5 mg/kg/hr IV for 4 hours, then 6.25 mg/kg/hr IV continuously for 67 hours
  • Hepatorenal syndrome: 150 mg/kg IV for 2 hours, followed by continuous infusion of 100 mg/kg for 5 days
  • Tracheostomy care: nebulization into tracheostomy: 1 to 10 mL of the 20% solution or 2 to 20 mL of the 10% solution every 2 to 6 hours; usual dose is 3 to 5 mL of the 20% solution or 6 to 10 mL of the 10% solution 3 to 4 times daily
  • Tracheostomy care: direct instillation into tracheostomy: 1 to 2 mL of a 10% or 20% solution may be given as often as every hour; usual dose is 1 to 2 mL of a 10% or 20% solution every 1 to 4 hours
  • Tracheostomy care: percutaneous intratracheal catheter: 1 to 2 mL of 20% solution or 2 to 4 mL of 10% solution every 1 to 4 hours via a syringe attached to the catheter
  • Tracheostomy care: intratracheal catheter into particular bronchopulmonary tree segment: 2 to 5 mL of the 20% solution via a syringe attached to the catheter

sub.title: Indications
sub.mono:
FDA-Labeled Indications
  • Acetaminophen overdose
  • Administration of anesthesia for procedure
  • Atelectasis, Due to mucous obstruction
  • Bronchopulmonary disease, acute
  • Complication of surgical procedure - Respiratory complication
  • Cystic fibrosis, Pulmonary complications; Adjunct
  • Diagnostic procedure on lower respiratory tract
  • Disease of respiratory system, chronic
  • Tracheostomy care
Non-FDA Labeled Indications
  • Hepatic failure, acute, Non-Acetaminophen Induced
  • Hepatorenal syndrome
  • Injury of lung
  • Malaria

sub.title: Contraindications
sub.mono:
• hypersensitivity to acetylcysteine
  • no specific contraindications have been identified with oral solution

sub.title: Precautions
sub.mono:
• Gastrointestinal:
  • -- vomiting may be intensified; monitor patients with risk of gastric hemorrhage
  • Hepatic:
  • -- encephalopathy due to hepatic failure may occur with oral solution; discontinue therapy to avoid further administration of nitrogenous substances
  • Immunologic:
  • -- anaphylactoid reactions, including a fatality, occurring 30 to 60 minutes following IV therapy initiation have been reported; monitoring recommended and discontinue therapy if symptoms cannot be medically managed
  • -- allergic symptoms including generalized urticaria have been reported with oral solution; discontinue if symptoms appear and cannot be medically managed
  • Respiratory:
  • -- asthma or history of bronchospasm with inhalation solution or IV administration; monitoring recommended and therapy should be discontinued if bronchospasm progresses
  • -- liquefied bronchial secretions may increase in volume, leading to airway obstruction if cough is inadequate; mechanical suction may be required
  • Other:
  • -- body weight less than 40 kg or fluid restricted patients; adjust total fluid to avoid fluid overload
  • -- evaporation of solvent in inhalation solution may occur, leading to increased concentration of drug; dilute nebulizing solution with appropriate amounts of sterile water for injection

sub.title: Breast Feeding
sub.mono: Micromedex: Infant risk cannot be ruled out.

5.title: Adverse Effects
5.mono:
Common
  • Dermatologic:Pruritus (1% to 3%), Rash (4% to 5%), Urticaria
  • Gastrointestinal:Diarrhea, Nausea (2% to 7%), Vomiting (9% to 12%)
Serious
  • Cardiovascular:Decreased cardiac function, Electrocardiogram abnormal
  • Immunologic:Anaphylactoid reaction (0.1% to 19%)
  • Neurologic:Status epilepticus
  • Respiratory:Bronchospasm, Respiratory distress

2.title: Class
2.mono:
• Acetaminophen Antidote
  • Amino Acid
  • Amino Acid Supplement
  • Diagnostic Agent, Bronchial
  • Mucolytic

7.title: Mechanism Of Action
7.mono:
• Inhalation: Acetylcysteine exerts its mucolytic action through its free sulfhydryl group, which opens the disulfide bonds and lowers mucus viscosity. This action increases with increasing pH and is most significant at pH 7 to 9. The mucolytic action of acetylcysteine is not affected by the presence of DNA.
  • Systemic: Acetylcysteine may protect against acetaminophen overdose-induced hepatotoxicity by maintaining or restoring hepatic concentrations of glutathione. Glutathione is required to inactivate an intermediate metabolite of acetaminophen that is thought to be hepatotoxic. In acetaminophen overdose, excessive quantities of this metabolite are formed because the primary metabolic (glucuronide and sulfate conjugation) pathways become saturated. Acetylcysteine may act by reducing the metabolite to the parent compound and/or by providing sulfhydryl for conjugation of the metabolite.

2.title: Metabolism
2.mono: Hepatic: deacetylated by the liver to cysteine or oxidation to diacetylcystine and subsequently metabolized

9.title: Administration
9.mono:
• Inhalation
    • 10% solution may be used undiluted
    • 20% solution may be diluted to a lesser concentration with sodium chloride inhalation solution, sodium chloride injection, or sterile water for injection or sterile water for inhalation
    • solution contains no antimicrobial agent; opened vials should be stored in the refrigerator and used within 96 hours
    • may be administered through nebulization into a face mask, mouth piece, tracheostomy, tent, or croupette, or through direct instillation intratracheally
  • Intravenous
    • color change of solution to slight pink or purple may occur; does not affect quality of product
    • preservative-free solution; discard unused portion
    • dilute in compatible solutions (D5W, 0.45%NaCl, sterile water for injection); diluted solution is stable for 24 hours at controlled room temperature
    • adjust total volume for patients less than 40 kg and for those requiring fluid restriction; Acetadote(R) is hyperosmolar (2600 milliosmoles/L [mOsm/L]), and the osmolarity of the solution is increased as the diluent volume is decreased; adjust osmolarity to physiologically safe level, generally not less than 150 mOsm/L in children
  • Oral
    • 20% acetylcysteine solution should be diluted with diet cola or other diet soft drink to a final concentration of 5% (add 3 mL of diluent for each 1 mL of 20% acetylcysteine solution; do not decrease the proportion of diluent)
    • water may be used as the diluent if administered via gastric tube or Miller-Abbott tube
    • dilution should be freshly prepared and administered within 1 hour
    • undiluted solutions can be stored for 96 hours in the refrigerator

10.title: Monitoring
10.mono:
• acetaminophen overdose: plasma or serum acetaminophen level prior to detoxification, as early as possible but no sooner than 4 hours postingestion of immediate-release acetaminophen; if the time of ingestion is unknown or if the initial acetaminophen level was drawn less than 4 hours after ingestion, obtain a second acetaminophen level; if extended-release acetaminophen was ingested, then initial acetaminophen level must be drawn not less than 8 hours postingestion and a second level must be drawn 4 to 6 hours following the initial level; repeat levels as long as potentially toxic.
  • acetaminophen overdose: hepatic function (AST, ALT, bilirubin, prothrombin time), renal function (creatinine and BUN), blood glucose, and electrolytes prior to detoxification and daily during the detoxification process
  • acetaminophen overdose: acetaminophen levels, AST, ALT, and INR; before end of 21-hour infusion
  • mucolytic agent: decreased mucous viscosity, a productive cough, and improvement in respiration are indicative of efficacy
  • signs of bronchospasm in patients with asthma or with a history of bronchospasm; during therapy
  • (IV) serious anaphylactoid reaction; during administration, and especially during the first 30 to 60 minutes following initiation of the infusion as reaction usually occur during this time period
  • (IV) acute flushing and erythema; particularly during administration of loading dose

11.title: How Supplied
11.mono:
• Generic
    • Capsule: 600 MG
    • Inhalation Solution: 10 %, 20 %
    • Intravenous Solution: 200 MG/ML
    • Oral Capsule: 500 MG
    • Oral Solution: 20 %
  • Acetadote
    Intravenous Solution: 200 MG/ML
  • GNC NAC 600
    Oral Capsule: 600 MG
  • NAC
    • Oral Capsule: 600 MG
    • Oral Powder: 1700 MG
  • Novaplus Acetylcysteine
    Intravenous Solution: 200 MG/ML

sub.title: Clinical Effects
sub.mono:
N-ACETYLCYSTEINE
OVERDOSE: Overdose with intravenous NAC most commonly causes an anaphylactoid response. Status epilepticus, cerebral edema, anoxic encephalopathy and death have been reported after massive intravenous overdose. ADVERSE EVENTS: N-acetylcysteine (NAC) is used therapeutically primarily as a mucolytic or as an antidote to acetaminophen overdose. COMMON: The primary toxicity of NAC consists of nausea/vomiting, particularly after oral therapy, and anaphylactoid reactions which can occur after intravenous therapy and may be life-threatening. INTRAVENOUS: Mild anaphylactoid reactions to intravenous NAC are fairly common, consisting of rash, flushing, urticaria and less often bronchospasm. These reactions most often occur during the initial infusion, and may be related to the dose and rate of administration. SEVERE: More severe reactions such as hypotension occur less often and are usually associated with an inadvertent overdose of intravenous NAC.

sub.title: Treatment
sub.mono:
N-ACETYLCYSTEINE
  • Decontamination: GI decontamination is usually not necessary because many patients experience vomiting with oral NAC.
  • Support: Anaphylactoid symptoms may develop; monitor patient airway. Bronchospasm should be treated aggressively. All patients developing a significant anaphylactoid reaction to NAC should be admitted to an ICU.
  • Acute allergic reaction: Symptoms are usually dose-dependent; epinephrine, antihistamines and steroids may be useful. Treatment guidelines: Flushing: No treatment indicated; continue NAC. Urticaria: Diphenhydramine 1 mg/kg and evaluate ongoing need for NAC. Angioedema: Diphenhydramine 1 mg/kg; stop NAC and reevaluate ongoing need for NAC. Respiratory symptoms: Stop NAC; treat symptoms with beta2 agonists, restart NAC if NO symptoms develop for 1 hour.
  • Nausea and vomiting: Monitor fluids and electrolytes. Replace fluids as indicated. Patient should be receiving 5% solution of NAC (not 10% or 20%). Metoclopramide: 1 mg/kg IV or IM 30 min before the NAC dose (extrapyramidal symptoms possible).
  • Seizure: IV benzodiazepines. Add barbiturates, propofol, or midazolam infusion for persistent seizures.
  • Hemodialysis: Based on limited data, IV NAC was removed by hemodialysis; mean hemodialysis clearance of 135 mL/min was reported.

sub.title: Range of Toxicity
sub.mono:
N-ACETYLCYSTEINE
TOXICITY: Limited data. Severe toxicity related to NAC administration is usually related to the development of acute allergic reactions following IV administration, which usually responds to supportive care, but in some cases deaths have occurred. PEDIATRIC: A 16 kg 30-month-old child died after developing status epilepticus, respiratory arrest and cerebral edema following 39,207 mg NAC (2,450 mg/kg) IV over 6.5 hours (normal dose 3,325 mg or 208 mg/kg). ADULT: A 21-year-old woman developed intractable seizures, cerebral edema followed by uncal herniation after inadvertently receiving 150 g of IV acetylcysteine over 32 hours; she remained in a persistent vegetative state. THERAPEUTIC DOSE: Acetaminophen Overdose, ORAL LOADING Dose: Adult OR Pediatric: 140 mg/kg orally as a 5% solution in a soft drink or juice. ORAL MAINTENANCE Dose: 70 mg/kg orally as a 5% solution in a soft drink or juice every 4 hrs for 72 hrs maintenance. NO change in dose is necessary in patients who have received activated charcoal. INTRAVENOUS: Adult: 150 mg/kg NAC in 200 mL D5W over 60 minutes, followed by 50 mg/kg 500 mL D5W over next 4 hrs, then 100 mg/kg in 1000 mL D5W over next 16 hrs. Pediatric: The amount of NAC administered is the same on a mg/kg basis, but doses are given in smaller amounts of D5W to avoid hyponatremia for excessive free water administration.

13.title: Clinical Teaching
13.mono:
• This drug may cause nausea, vomiting, fever, drowsiness, clamminess, and chest tightness. The oral form may also cause other gastrointestinal symptoms.
  • Warn patient that the drug has a disagreeable odor. This is normal and becomes less noticeable as therapy continues.
  • Advise patient that liquid inside the vial may turn clear to light purple. This is normal and does not change efficacy.
  • If oral dose is used for treatment for acetaminophen overdose, advise patient to report vomiting within 1 hour of administration as dose may need to be repeated.
